29306217.review:
Fortix, gra która nie jedną osobę doprowadzi, do wściekłości, lub też rozpaczy. Przynajmniej osoby próbujące przejść grę na 100%.
Jest to mało skomplikowana w mechanice, gra zręcznościowa, w której naszym zadaniem jest, przejąć tereny zajęte przez mrocznego władcę smoków.
Napotkamy tu parę, różnych w mechanice przeciwników i wieże strażnice, wszystkich ich pokonamy za pomocą przejęcia terenu, podczas gdy oni sami znajdują się na danym kawałku który "odcinamy".
W całej grze pomogą nam zróżnicowane, specjalne umiejętności, pojawiające się losowo na mapie i katapulty niszczące wrogie wieże.
Przejście gry na niskim poziomie trudności, nie stanowi absolutnie żadnego trudu, dzięki czemu gra może idealnie się odnaleźć jako, gra na przeczekanie nudy, kiedy oczekujemy na coś, na ten przykład pobranie gry.
Dla bardziej zapalonych graczy, mamy poziom "niemożliwy", znacznie utrudnia grę, zmuszając nas do większego pośpiechu poprzez czas na przejście mapy, przyśpieszenie przeciwników i pocisków wysyłanych przez wieże.
Pomimo najwyższego poziomu, gra nadal nie powinna stanowić dużego problemu, dla bardziej wprawionych graczy. W poszukiwaniu wrażeń z wysokiego poziomu trudności, odsyłam do drugiej odsłony tej gry, której ostatnie 3 plansze stanowią prawdziwy pokaz umiejętności.

Plusy:
+Prostota, która mimo wszystko potrafi mocno wciągnąć.
+Na najwyższym poziomie trudności gra staję się miłym wyzwaniem.
+Powrót do przeszłości, dzięki mechanice ze starych gierek, które można było ogrywać na przeglądarce.
+Zróżnicowana mechanika przeciwników.
+Gra daję możliwość podejścia do poziomów na dwa sposoby, nie jedynie zbieranie katapult, ale i własnoręczne niszczenie wież obronnych.
+Łatwy sposób na zdobycie kolejnej gry na 100%.
+Sposób na zabicie nudnej godzinki-dwóch, czy też przeczekanie na pobranie gry.
+Powiedzmy sobie szczerze, dostajemy grę dającą sporo frajdy, za niecałe pięć złotych.

Minusy:
-Spora losowość w trudności przechodzenia plansz, w zależności od wylosowanego powerupa, gra może stać się banalna, bądź też niezwykle frustrująca.
-Większość poziomów nie stanowi dużego wyzwania.
-Gra może nie odnaleźć się u osób lubiących nowe, duże tytuły.
-Z czasem gra staję się monotonna, mechanika obejmuje jedynie ruch w czterech kierunkach, dlatego zalecam przechodzenie gry na wyższym poziomie trudności.

Osobiście darzę Fortix sporą sympatią, kupiłem ją jako grę do zabicia czasu, powspominania dawnych czasów i skończenia gry w pełni. Wszystkie moje wymagania zostały spełnione, dlatego z całą pewnością, mogę polecić Fortix, jako grę wartą uwagi.

24381688.review:
[h1] Fortix [/h1]

Fortix foi desenvolvido pela Nemesys Games e teve seu lançamento no dia 14 de Abril de 2010.

Acabei comprando o jogo por ter pouco dinheiro em minha carteira Steam e me surpreendi. Sua jogabilidade é simples, sua trilha sonora é agradável, e ainda há conquistas e cartas. Também devo dizer que não encontrei nenhum bug enquanto jogava, o que nos leva a crer que o jogo foi feito com muito carinho pelos desenvolvedores.

Acredito que o único ponto negativo seja a quantidade de fases, levando o jogador a zerar em 3 horas no máximo, exceto caso ele queira 100% das conquistas, como foi meu caso.

Enfim, recomendo o jogo caso tenha pouco dinheiro em sua carteira e gosta de jogos do tipo.

Nota: 9/10

22386878.review:
Even though Fortix is a pretty old game, it's a lot of fun. 

It reminds me of the days of QIX but with a Fantasy spin and more interesting enemies and with an actual mini story. The game takes QIX mechanics and pits you against dragons and to win each level you have to capture the forts on the map. You can win by default by claiming enough of the map regardless. 

The music isn't bad and doesn't get old too quickly, at least if you're not totally bad at it. Simple graphics are all this game needs and it does it well. 

In terms of the Achievements, most of them are pretty standard things to get and won't make you work too hard. You'll get a lot of them just from playing and beating the game. Only three Achievements require any sort of skill. One of them is downright hard, but as I started playing yesterday and finally managed to get it, not too bad. 

It's a good game to pick up and put down, however it may drag you in for an extended stay when you get so frustrated that the level is so easy and you made a silly mistake. 

There are two control options for this game, mouse (casual) or keyboard (hard, but better for mastery.)
Options are pretty limited but there's not much to need.

One minor annoying thing I found, was no way to kill my profile and start over if I'd lost too many lives. You're stuck with whatever you've done unless you change difficulties. 

However, for what it is, it's a great fun time. Technically it could have a lot of replayabliity, if you really enjoy this style of game. 

I'd get it on sale or in a bundle. But regardless, it's good fun. 

8/10

Игра простая по сути, но захватывающая. Сюжет вторичен и неважен. Раньше подобные игры обходились порой вообще без сюжета. 
Итак, ваша задача бегать человечком и отхватываете куски территории, цель захватить территории с замком и башнями, враги вам естественно будут мешать. Вот и все! Уровней не много, но больше уже будет лишка. 

Плюсы:
- Простое и понятное управление 4 кнопки на клавиатуре. 
- Приятная графика и оформление. 
- Музычка простая и ненавязчивая.
- Много ачивок.
- Карточки.
- Недорогая, а если со скидкой брать, то вообще копейки. Вообщем стоит своих денег. 

Минус:
- Игрушка, не рассчитана на большие широкоэкраные мониторы. В полноэкранном режиме растягивается на весь монитор и приобретает безумный вид. В оконном режиме может выглядеть слегка мелковатой на больших мониторах.

Вывод: Хорошая игра, которая стоит своих денег и проходиться быстро, но при этом в нее всегда можно переиграть с удовольствием.

18577769.review:
Mais um daqueles jogos incríveis que você acha na Steam por um preço absurdamente barato. Fortix foi desenvolvido pela Nemesys Games e teve seu lançamento na Steam no dia 10 de Abril de 2010.

Eu sinceramente achei que o jogo não seria tão divertido, já que pelo seu preço é de se dúvidar e olhando algumas imagens e também alguns vídeos no Youtube ainda me peguei pensando se o jogo era bom, mas como o valor era extremamente baixo eu resolvi comprar. Fortix ficou na minha lista de jogos para jogar a um bom tempo e finalmente resolvi por as mãos no título e instalar ele em meu computador e para minha surpresa Fortix é um jogo muito bem elaborado e feito com muito carinho pelos desenvolvedores já que tudo nele funciona quase que perfeitamente, sendo um jogo perfeito para os jogadores que querem passar o tempo e se divertir em um jogo divertido e sem muita dificuldade, ou seja ... perfeito tanto para o público casual quanto para o público que apenas procura um bom jogo por um ótimo preço.

Fortix não conta com um enredo elaborado e muito menos com personagens cativantes, mas tudo se sustenta de forma tranquila já que a jogatina é o ponto mais forte do jogo e é realmente divertido ver a dificuldade aumentando conforme o jogador passa por diversos níveis ao longo da sua pequena campanha, que seria um dos pontos negativos já que o jogo é bem curtinho, mas pelo preço? não tem como reclamar.

Pontos positivos:

+ Jogabilidade 
+ Level Design
+ Simplicidade e boa dificuldade
+ Boa Trilha Sonora
+ Preço
+ Cartas Steam + Conquistas

Pontos negativos: 

- Curta duração (Se você não é jogador de ir atrás de conquistas vai zerar o jogo em 2 - 3 horas)

Fortix ganhou um segundo jogo e pelo que vi está com gráficos muito melhores e uma jogabilidade muito melhor! mal espero para colocar minhas mãos no segundo título!

É um ótimo jogo para se passar o tempo e se divertir.

Eu recomendo.

Fortix tem um gameplay singular focado em conquista de território e destruição de dragões simplesmente desenhando uma linha no chão com seu personagem, essa linha não pode ser atingida por nenhum disparo inimigo ou tocada por um dragão, existem cinco tipos de dragões (contando com o chefe, que só aparece na ultima fase), e mesmo que pareça simples, o jogo é muito viciante e tem um fator replay neutro (na verdade só terminei o jogo principal e metade das conquistas, só joguei por metade do tempo que o jogo ficou aberto), além de tudo é MUITO BARATO! Realmente vale pra quem gosta de indies e quer um bom passatempo. 
-----------------------------------------
Fortix has a unique gameplay focused on the conquest of territory and destruction of dragons simply by drawing a line on the floor with your character, this line can not be hit by any enemy shooting or touched by a dragon, there are five types of dragons (counting the boss which appears only in the last level), and even that seems simple, the game is very addictive and has a neutral replay factor (actually just finished the main game and half of achievements, only played for half as long as the was game been open), beside it is VERY CHEAP! Really worth for those who like indie and want a good pastime.

17664163.review:
This game in 4min
https://youtu.be/SRBYQfUQqJg

Simple gameplay.
You play a greedy knight that runs around in 12 kingdoms on lines that you "own" on the board and he takes land by squaring it off.
Dragons and the current land owners will try to kill you when they find you on their land.
When you venture out some dragons will come at you and/or shoot fire at you.
There is also the towers that will fire on you, and a bat that has your scent, traveling on your lines hunting you down.
If any of these touch you or your line when your taking land your dead and the bat will just kill you outright on your own land but can not follow you out.
Water, cliffs, and sand will slow you down, then there are also impassable walls (dragons can fly over these).
If you can take the area with the crossed axes you'll launch a catapult and take out one of the towers.
You win by destroying all enemies or taking enough land to satisfy the gods. 

"Crush your enemies. See them driven before you. Hear the lamentations of their women."

16868212.review:
Many years ago, there was a freeware game called something like "nuclear reactor", or "radiation", where there were "neutrons" bouncing around on linear tracks, like Pong.  Later, there was a microsoft game that came in a supplementary "game pack" called Jezzball which allowed you to cut spaces in half.....

... Many years later, they're re-released... as "Fortix".    This is a very quick, fun little game about "walling off" chunks of a playarea to capture them.  Anything inside the area you capture, becomes yours.  Enemies are neutralised, etc...    

I really enjoyed playing this.. It was a very brief, fun little walk down memory lane, a familiar old format, in a fun "medieval" theme...

Great for a dollar :)

16295808.review:
Daumen hoch oder Dauemen runter sind zwei relativ schwammige Dinge, wenn es auf den Preis ankommt!

Daumen runter gibt es von mir zwar nicht, aber hier meine Eindrücke die einen roten Daumen rechtfertigen würden.

1. Keine Abwechslung im Missionsdesign, da man immer die gleiche Aufgabe hat, fir Burg und eventuelle Türme einzukreisen.

2. Wenig Gegnertypen, wenig Abwechslung bei den Typen - es gibt nur Drachen und Türme!!!

3. Frustmomente, da die Türme so randommäßig feuern, das man kaum vorwärtskommt ohne Risiko zu gehen teilweise. Es gibt kein Interval wie sie maximal feuern können, manchmal rennt man 4 Sekunden im freien ohne das sie feuern und teilweise schon in der ersten Sekunde... reaktionszeit echt extrem und bei 1 Leben auf letztem Schwierigkeitsgrad etwas...
Wobei er auch unmöglich sein soll ;)

4. Kein "Story" die Texte sind für mich keine Story, sondern wie in einem Flahgame!

5. Missionsanzahl ist so gering, dass man kaum neues sieht, teilweise sogar Wiederholung der Maps(einmal ist es mir aufgefallen, nur die Gegner änderten sich)

6. KI ist mies...

Was gut an dem Spiel ist:

1. PREIS!!! Bei einem Triple-A-Titel wären die Daumen hier alle unten, aber für 1 Euro ist es definitiv okay!

2. kurzweiliges Arcade-Spiel und gut für zwischendurch

3. Archievements

4. mehrere Schwierigkeitsgrade (4 Stück)

5. Zauber, die einem kurzzeitig helfen

6. altbewährtes Spielprinzip, bei dem man Gegner auch in Fallen locken kann - leider ist die KI nicht die beste...

7. verschiedene Untergründe die unterschiedliche Bewegungsgeschwindigkeiten zulassen uns somit Taktik erfordern.

8. meist fair verteilte Katapultsymbole(diese aktivieren die Katapulte, welche die Türme plätten die einen angreifen; man muss diese Symbole einzäunen um sie zu aktivieren)

9. auch zu win 7 kompatibel, zumindest bei mir!

Fazit:

Für den Preis absolut ok, die 5 Stunden waren spassig, nur der letzte Schwierigkeitsgrad ist absolut FRUST!!
Hab mich öfters gezwungen auszumachen, da die Türme teilweise so schnell schießen dass man die Krise bekommt...

Das Spielptrinziep ist schon recht alt und kenne ich vom C64:
Man muss Stück für Stück das Gebiet des Feindes Erobern indem man das Gebiete "umrahmt".  Dabei läuft man mir seinem Männchen am Rand des Gebietes entlang und nutzt Gelegenheiten sozusagen einen Zaun im Feindesgebiet zu bauen, während zB Kanonen auf einen Feuern oder Monster, vorrangig Drachen, einen angreifen.

Taktik wie auch Geschick ist gefragt um schneller als der Feind zusein und, gegen die Uhr, den Feind zubesiegen, indem man die feindlichen Gebäude umzäunt.  Dabei sollte man ein wenig Frustresistenz besitzen da es nicht immer gleich auf anhieb klappt zu gewinnen und so mehrere Anläufe notwendig sind.

Fortix ist ein kurzweiliges Arcade-Spiel das ich nur jeden Empfehlen kann. Die Archievments sind in Fortix einfacher zu erreichen als in Fortix2. Dennoch kann ich beide Empfehlen. 

Ein lokaler Highscore macht es auch interresant mal Freunde und Bekannte zu einem Spiel heraus zu fordern.

15498129.review:
Fortix is a strategic puzzle game in which you must capture the castles by making lines and rectangles. There are turrets and dragons ready to kill you all around and you have a set amount of lives per stages.

The game is really stressful, because if you die in a set of levels, you will start over at the first one. Also in the later difficulties, with how hard it is to make pixel perfect squares, you will die to random 1x1 pixel bumps you have made while capturing terrain. This game could have been pretty good, I like the idea. There's even more bad things about the game...

This is a "puzzle" kind of game, but the enemies and bonuses doesn't spawn at the same place if you retry or start over. That makes it so you can win many levels just by re-trying until you get a "Stop-time" bonus in a convenient spot and clear the level in 20 seconds.

The game can be completed in less than 30 minutes (even on Impossible difficulty), but at least it's cheap...

I do not think it is too bad, but I cannot recommend it, way too punishing, it's 1$ though... So if you want to try a new type of puzzle/strategy game, sure, try it. Personally, I found it too punishing and frustrating. I also felt like I had no real control over certain of my deaths.

Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Casual snake type of game.



[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]


You are able to change the music volume by clicks. Every click changes the volume by 10.
You are able to change the sound volume by clicks. Every click changes the volume by 10.
You can play this game in fullscreen or windowed mode.
You are able to change the difficulty. Easy to impossible.
You can not change the resolution size. 


[h1]About the game.[/h1]

The game is very easy to understand. You play with a knight that makes a border line. When the border line has reach the other white line, it will convert into your land and you will claim it. The knight is able to die if it gets hit by an enemy. You will also lose a life is the border line took a hit by an enemy. So be careful when you are making a huge line in one go. You will win when you have completed the objective on that level. You can also kill dragons or destroy turrets by creating land. Sometimes this is necessary to reach the "perfect victory condition". There are also powerups to help you on your way. You have to win the level within the time limit.

You can play the game with the mouse or keyboard.
They will ask you if you want to do the tutorial or skip it.
Powerups.
Able to restart a level.
No options during the game.
Calming music.

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

-------------------

I Give this game a 6/10

No tengo ni idea de si existe un género que defina el de este juego, aunque cuando era más joven recuerdo haberme encontrado más de una vez alguna que otra recreativa muy parecida en jugabilidad a este.

Básicamente nuestro objetivo es capturar la mayoría del escenario en cada nivel con nuestro caballero, y para ello tendremos que ir delimitando zonas que al ser cerradas sobre si mismas pasarán a ser de nuestro territorio (es mucho más sencillo de entender viendo cualquier vídeo así que no me explayaré de más en esto, aunque incomprensiblemente en la ficha de la tienda no hay ninguno). A medida que vayamos avanzando por los niveles habrá mayor variedad y cantidad de enemigos, empezando por los básicos como las torres de defensa o los dragones, pero siempre que estemos en nuestra zona segura sus ataques no tendrán efecto sobre nosotros. El problema es que para conseguir más territorio tendremos que salir de ella constantemente y ahí radica el peligro, hay que estar muy atento porque si algo se puede criticar es que es muy fácil dejar a nuestro personaje fuera de la zona segura por apenas unos píxeles sin darnos cuenta, y ello obviamente origina que muera varias veces de forma aparentemente injusta.

En principio es relativamente fácil de completar a nivel normal, pero el verdadero reto está en el nivel más alto donde la velocidad de los ataques aumenta y cualquier error se paga muy caro. También completar todos los logros puede resultar un verdadero desafío.

Encima cuesta solo 1 euro sin oferta, de las mejores propuestas que hay en el catálogo por ese precio sin duda alguna.

12886249.review:
Fortix is a cracking little casual indie game thats furiously fast and ferociously fun to play.  The basic premise is something akin to 'Join the Dots' meets basic geometry.  You take control of an intrepid knight that must be manoeuvred around and across various maps in order to capture the enemy castle.  The action is displayed in birds-eye view.

The knight must be moved out from a safezone which starts on the outer border of the map.  While in the safezone the knight is immune to any deadly enemy attacks.  Rectangles must be drawn from one part of the safezone to another to cut down the enemys control of the land (map).  This must be done with all manner of obstacles ready to kill the knight, while being up against the clock.

Of course the further into the map the safezone encroaches the less space the knight has to avoid deadly obstacles.  These include: two types of cannon ball firing towers and, a multitude of dragons that swoop down or shoot fireballs in an attempt to kill your knight.  These must be avoided by ensuring that your knight is in the safezone when hit and not in the midst of drawning a rectangle.  If the knight is hit while drawning a polygon then a life is lost.  If this isnt enough of a challenge note that the map must be conquered against the clock.

Fear not for the knight has a few actions they can perform to help you win.  They can 'capture' triggers to destroy enemy towers, or trap dragons in a part of the safezone killing them instantly.  Special tokens can also be 'captured' that provide a number of neat abilities such as: temporary invincibility, stopping cannonballs, killing dragons, receiveing an extra life or stopping time.  To capture a trigger or token a polygon must be drawn around the item on the map.

There is one campaign which covers twelve maps.  It can be replayed through four difficulty levels: Easy, Normal, Hard and Impossible.  Difficulty affects time available, starting lives, the reaction speed amongst others.

With rudimentary controls the game is easy to pick-up.  While graphics are basic they are well rendered and provide a more than fitting medieval ambience that goes perfectly with the incredibly catchy music played in the background.  No bugs were encountered during twelve plus hours of play.

Overall I really enjoyed playing and beating this game. It has that 'just one more go' addictive quality, which kept me playing.  Easily worth the money.

这坑爹游戏其实就是困兽斗。通过画格子来战斗。其实这理念不错，格子里有各种各样的攻击道具。攻占各种各样的城堡。游戏处于及格线左左右右。

但是，我标注的是不推荐。

为什么不推荐呢？因为我真的受够这货的操作了。作为一款游戏，操作流畅方便是必须的。然而，这游戏的操作非常的渣。划线非常容易走过，而且你离开边线起码有个保障吧，比如同时按下shift，alt什么的，但这货没有，只有轻轻的那么卡顿一下，这就导致了很多时候游戏里的小混蛋做出的反应并不是你想要的。游戏分割划分也非常小，有时候你画个复杂的东西，你都不知道怎么回去。

而且游戏的画面很不怎么样，给人一种廉价的感觉，不过还没廉价到像素的境界。

作为小游戏，这货算是可玩性不错，但是操作性太渣。等人的时候没有游戏消磨了，这货也算不错的选择。

不过话又说回来，0.99刀的游戏，还指望什么呢？

[b]Intro:[/b]
I bought this game as part of a group of games in the categorie of cheap.
When i first played it, i didn't expect much of it, something you'd find on a mobile phone rather than the Steam Desktop platform, yet it turns out to be quite entertaining

[b]Game overview[/b]
The goal of the game is to defeat the red-marked tower by strategically conquering land. Walking over 'enemy soil' creates a thin line where you walked, and when crossed with your own land, you gain the smallest patch (e.g. if you take over a small plot of land, naturally it wouldn't grant you the whole map from that small piece.) Which requires some planning as to how to win

But beware, when hit by a dragon, turret or other enemies, you lose a life, and the land you were just about to conquer
This further enhances the strategical part, between quick turns with minimum risk and large leaps with more gained land

[b]Recommended to:[/b]
Since i have Steam active on my computer nearly all the time, and want to play a short game this is what comes to my mind, so i recommend this to people who wanna play casual games instead of the big titles, if you're just looking to pass the time, or don't have the focus/time for anything more fancy

11822290.review:
A fleeting joy, but a joy nonetheless, is the best way to describe Fortix, which seems to be the combination-lovechild of an beginner's art project and beginner's programming project. While the art is interesting enough and carries what it needs to carry, you aren't going to be entranced, and the gameplay, while a bit repetitive, offers enough challenge to keep you on board for long enough to at least finish the game's achievements and receive the three offered card drops.
The game offers two control schemes, keyboard or mouse, each with it's own advantages, which is an interesting and not-often-seen twist. The game offers standard option controls including windowed mode (always a plus) and the ability to mute the in-game music, which you will most likely be doing after it loops the third time.
The gameplay is difficult enough to match each mode of play from easiest to hardest, with the hardest being worthy of the title. The game offers bonuses to be roped-off and captured in order to gain short-lasting special abilities such as a temporary speed boost, temporary halting of cannon fire, or the killing off of one of the infuriating dragons. The level designs vary and offer up a challenge as you gain access to higher levels. Be careful not to lose all of your lives, though! In levels with multiple castles to capture you have to restart from the first castle in that level if you run out of chances.
For the price, I recommend picking up the game, for the trading cards and easier-than-usual achievements. While you won't be returning again and again as if the game is a nasty habit, it is highly worth being a quick guilty casual-gaming guilty pleasure.

Qui se souviens de Qix  de Taito??

Et bien Fortix c'est pareil que Qix sauf que sa se déroule dans des décors médiévaux. On balade un petit sprite sous les traits d'un preux chevalier, en dessinant des lignes en ses deplacant il doit creer des zones qui permettent de capturer du territoire (au départ, le bord de l'écran), et atteindre un certain pourcentage de capture pour terminer le niveau.

Dans Qix il y avait qu'un seul monstre ( le Qix d'ailleurs ), là il y a des dragons qui circule dans les niveaux, des tours de défenses etc. etc. Le but est d'éviter ces dragons et petits pièges vicieux, mais les capturer rapporte plus de points. Plus l'aire de jeu se rétrécit et plus il est difficile de manoeuvrer le chevalier.

Pour aider notre héros il y a tout un panel d'item qui par exemple arrête le temps, accelere sa vitesse... Dans les niveaux de difficulté les plus élevé le challenge est de taille.

Graphiquement c'est mignon et la musique est sympa à petits doses ( au bout de 3 heures on devient débile)...

Idéal pour tuer le temps 10 minutes et assez hardcore par moment pour les plus tenaces.

Note globale: 15/20

11245250.review:
[h1]Small but likeable top-down strategy[/h1]

This is a really small game, but it still takes a bit of time to get to like it. The basic idea is very simple: capture enemy territory by moving your one character along a "baseline", where you are safe from attacks, and cutting off pieces of the territory by leaving the safe baseline. While you're out in the open, you're prone to attacks from cannonballs and dragons, so it's crucial to get a good timing, and even apply some basic strategy here and there.

There isn't much more to it, really, so the game is quite easy to master, but the intricacies of some of the later levels ask for some quick reactions while moving into the open. There is something addictive in trying to finish every level and outwit the dragons; and there are some nice steam-achievement and even trading cards on offer. So if you can pick this one up at a low price: just spend the money, but don't expect a great game in return, just a quick but tasty snack.

Gameplay: 20/30
Graphics: 12/20 (basic really, but still with some atmosphere)
Sound: 5/10
Longeliveity: 10/20
Stability/techical: 15/20 (I had a couple of sudden minimalizes, but the game just continued in the background so no big deal).

Overall: 62/100

I've actually played it for a little more than usual, trying to get perfects on all the castles and I will probably play for an additional hour trying to do the same. 10329113.review: Fun little game.  This is basically etch-a-sketch warrior.  You have a map that you walk around with the arrow keys so just up, down, left, & right.  You unlock or reclaim it by making or completing a square back to the baseline or the edge of the map.  This "base line" will change as you chew your way into the map.  The interesting bit is while you are trying to do this turrets will fire cannonballs at you and dragons and various baddies will come after you.  You die when they hit your incomplete line.  That reminded me of the old snake games you used to play on cellphones before they had color screens.  Your line is completed when you make a box.  You can trap dragons by boxing them in and the same with turrets.  Whatever is within that box is reclaimed or defeated.  There are various powerups and trigger points that will activate your attack forces to start firing at the turrets to make life a little easier for you.    It is a simple game mechanic that is quite fun.  Well worth the asking price on steam.

Remember Qix from the '80s ? If yes did you enjoy that game ? If yes again, stop reading and just get this. If no, stop reading and skip this.

For those who don't know Qix, it's a simple arcade game where you conquer territory by drawing lines across the screen and trapping a monster in an enclosed space.
Fortix is based on the same basic gameplay, but with a few twists - you need to conquer specific forts and there's various powerups to help you, and turrets and dragons to stop you. It's all nicely done and controls smoothly.
It may or may not keep you busy for more than a few hours, but for a single buck it'll offer good value for money.

9883589.review:
[h1]At the Time of Writing[/h1]
[b]Game:[/b] Fortix
[b]Price:[/b] $0.99*
[b]Genre:[/b] Arcade/Puzzle
[b]Time Played:[/b] 14 hours
[b]Personal Enjoyment Rating:[/b] ☺☺☺☺☺(out of 5)

[b]Links I Found Helpful**[/b]
A Youtube review by [b]MrEmeralddragon[/b][url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6gd4T4jrH7U]http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6gd4T4jrH7U[/url]

[h1]General[/h1]
This little game is truly a glittering gem. It is outrageously fun! Indeed, I would say that it is worth more than a mere dollar.

There is also Fortix2 available on Steam, and although I should say that all of the level layouts in Fortix are also in Fortix2, I should also say that Fortix is a little bit more of a challenge than Fortix2.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Your objective is to capture the vast majority of territory of each level. This game is apparently based on an old game called "Qix" (before my time, so I can't tell you more than that). You capture territory by walking your knight off of his baseline and tracing out boxes, which once you go back to the baseline will then be claimed. Life is made a little more hazardous by towers that shoot at you, various creatures that want to eat you, and changes in ground type which slow you down.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
One can use the mouse, but using the keyboard gives you much more precise control over your knight. I certainly found the keyboard more intuitive to use. You need fast fingers if you play in hard mode!

[h1]Storyline[/h1]
There is one, but it isn't much of one. Very basic, there is a bad guy, you must complete all the levels and defeat the bad guy. I must say though, that really not every game needs a plot so I can't count it as a con.

[h1]Sound[/h1]
Really fun medieval jolly music. I also enjoyed listening to the little noises the dragons make.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
I enjoyed the artwork a great deal. There are plenty of different looking textures to help you tell ground types apart. So, functional and nice to look at. The dragons are really cute!

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[b]+ [/b]different difficulty settings making it simplistic or a bit of a challenge
[b]+ [/b]different ways to control your knight
[b]+ [/b]pleasant atmosphere
[b]+ [/b]simple objective, but hurdles between you and victory
[b]+ [/b]awfully cheap
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[b]- [/b]movement can be a bit awkward and sometimes not as responsive as you might like

[h1]Help Me Help You[/h1]
[b]If you did not find this review helpful,[/b] I would really appreciate your constructive criticism - tell me why it wasn’t helpful for you. It’s my hope to make the reviews that I do take the time to write up, as helpful as they possibly can be.

[h1]Rothana's Steam Review Archive[/h1]
For those that are interested in seeing more of my reviews, I have set up an archive of them at an external website. I don't earn anything off of this at all, it's just a little side project that I add to when I can. Steam won't let me create a direct link though, so you'll need to make your own way to the URL I describe now: [b]rothana dot weebly dot com[/b]

Overall, this game was pretty decent if you can get it for cheap. The story dictates that you are a knight trying to take back castles; however, this is just that "capture a certain amount of the area by drawing lines with your character" kind of game. The whole point is to "box" off sections of the map, capturing cannons or points to make completing the level easier. In the end, just capture the castle and forget the rest of the map, as this is the easiest path to victory. This game just ends up being a bit of a time waster, and is good for a nostalgic trip into childhood, replaying a remake of an older game from days past.

Don't buy this game unless it is under $1 or in a really good package deal.

9567334.review:
Very cheap game, the price of a mobile app, and yet so much more gameplay and story. A great, simple game, with fun, engaging, simple and tried-and-true gameplay mechanics. For less than a dollar you can get a game that is better than some $5+ games I own.

Simple story, you are a knight who has returned to his homeland to reclaim his family's throne from an evil wizard. However, this isn't some strategy game where you build up resources or units, nor is this an in-depth RPG or hack-n-slash. No, this game is a thing of pure beauty. 

It is simple. You control a knight (Sir Fortix), and you move around the map, cutting out swathes of land. The more land you get, the higher your score. However, there are enemy turrets that can hit you or your drawn line, and dragons that fly around the map and can kill you. There are also enemies that travel around the lines, trying to hunt you down. How do you defeat them? Simple, outline them. Simply run around them so that they are trapped in the piece of land you cut out. Capture catapult triggers to shoot catapults at the enemy turrets and destroy them. You have a set number of lives and a time limit, although each is more than enough I think. This isn't as easy as it sounds, as enemies can fill your screen and multiple turrets can send cannon balls flying everywhere, while you dodge through, vanquishing enemies, capturing triggers and power up, and slowly but surely conquer the map.

Many levels, often with other levels within them, a great, simple, and cheap game that focuses on gameplay and fun. For $0.99? It is a steal and I highly reccomend it. Plus, it comes with trading cards, so you can get emoticons, backgrounds, and badges from this game, and for getting access to this, the price seems even better!

It is a little older, so the resolution is a little off, although setting it to full screen makes it more than playable imo. I've heard of issues with this game on Windows 8.1, but I run Windows 8 64 bit and it runs perfectly.

I do recommend this game, 8/10

8673138.review:
I like this game. I also hate this game. But overall I like it. It does not necessarily take long to finish the levels. But if you want to spend more time you just go and beat the impossible difficulty. Achievements keep up the motivation.

Fortix may be described as a capture-the-map game in which the player has to capture certain areas of the map. This is done by venturing into the uncaptured map and basically fencing off a part of the terrain. Once both ends of the fence are connected to your baseline (initially surrounding the playing field) you claim the area inside. Movement is restricted to vertical and horizontal and fencing-off may be interrupted by a number of hazards of increasing difficulty (and annoyance ;) ).

If you, for whatever reason, remember the Game Boy game Qix you know the basic mechanics of Fortix. And if you enjoyed the former you will probably enjoy the latter, like I do.

What really annoyed me on the harder difficulty was that I couldn't always clearly determine whether I had started fencing off. Since part of the fence to-be-build is hidden under the player I often stepped of the baselline and got attacked without ever realizing the danger I had put myself in. Keeping enemy reactions in sight is hard when you are concentrating on inching by some tower fearing you will miss the baseline again and die.
I sort of like the way you are stopped when you run into a corner but I'd much rather prefer a more direct control over when to step off the baseline. Fortix 2 has running which incidentally keeps you on the baseline - both by holding CTRL - a technique similar to what I have in mind. I'd like to have a key like SHIFT that I have to hold to be able to step off the baseline, also canceling the stopping technique.
I could also imagine releasing SHIFT would result in the player returning to the closest point on the baseline. Although I understand that not having that return mechanism may be a deliberate decision in order to keep the overall difficulty of the game at a decent level.
At times I thought it might be useful to have a key for making the player backtrack on the current fence - a move almost impossible to make after taking the first corner.

As I said before, I recommend this game as I do its sequel which I will continue to be furious with now.

7864946.review:
Etch-a-sketch meets strategy. You draw lines to divide up territory, making sure that neither yourself nor your line is hurt by the obstacles along the way, and when you've captured specific territory or a certain amount, you succeed. The principle is simple and it's fun enough.

They certainly know how to set difficulty levels. The default of easy is just that as it allows time for correction. The impossible difficulty will give you a run for your money as, try though I did, I could not get perfect on the last level on the impossible difficulty. This makes it an adequate choice whether you are looking for a brief distraction or a challenge.

The game is very sensitive and seems to expect extremely precise timing. I say this because often enough I tried to reconnect to a previous section only to be a sliver off, usually leading to my demise. This is compounded by the fact that anything and everything, including your own character and score callouts, seems to be in the way of being able to see where you are and whether you've started a new line, exposing yourselft to danger. Often, I would accidentally end up on a border that was a sliver off of the one I had come from only to find myself dead because I had unknowingly just exposed myself to a nearby danger. There are also many random elements like which tower will fire when, where pick-ups appear and which way dragons will go making it much harder to plan things out. When all of these things are so meaningful alone that they could determine success or failure, it becomes increasingly frustrating on the impossible difficulty because you fail due to many factors seemingly beyond your control.

3452522.review:
At this point, the only thing you need to know about Fortix 1 is not to bother with it. Though it might seem trivial to complain when it only costs a dollar, the fact of the matter remains that with the release of Fortix 2 (which includes all of 1's levels) the original has been made completely obsolete and redundant.

Not that it was particularly worthwhile to begin with. With only a dozen or so strongholds to defeat, most of which comprise but a single level, Fortix is over before it feels like it's even started. The different difficulty settings do nothing to create replay value, only increasing the speed of enemies and lowering the generous amount of extra lives you receive, as the game is very easy even set on impossible.

In short, even having gotten it for free, I feel cheated to have wasted my time playing Fortix. The level designs are terribly dull and the presentation so basic and repetitive that the it amounts to being little more than a glorified flash game or demo. Save your dollar, or better yet find it a friend and get Fortix 2 instead. It provides the better experience through and through, and although I think the core gameplay of Fortix is rather enjoyable itself, this is simply an extremely poor representation of it that serves no purpose but to take up space in your Steam library.

6505478.review:
QIXやギャルズパニックでお馴染みの陣取りゲーム。脱衣要素はありません。

基本ルールは派生作品と似たような感じで敵の妨害を避けたり撃退したりしつつ
特定の領土を獲得するか一定の大きさまで領土を拡大すればクリアとなる。
地形によって移動速度が異なることや補助効果のあるアイテム等が存在する他
複雑なルールは特に存在していない。

QIXでは敵基準に陣を分割することによって99.9%を狙えたがFortixでは
常に分割後の小さい方の領土を獲得することになるためそういったプレイはできない。

ステージ数は全22。初期難易度のEASYであればギミックを使うことなくさっくり進むため
クリアだけならボリュームはそれほど無く手軽に遊ぶことが出来る。
値段も普通に買っても$1もしないので普通にお勧めできる。

難易度は5種類あって敵の速度や攻撃速度が高難易度になるほど上昇していく。
最高難易度は禿げ上がる恐れがあるため注意。


自分の環境が悪いんだと思いますがプレイ中にキー入力が一瞬効かない事があったり
一定方向に入力がいれっぱになってしまうことがちょくちょくありました。
高難易度プレイ時にそういった操作ミスをするとかなりストレスになるため
ガチでやるなら入力装置はまともなもの使った方が精神衛生上宜しいかもしれません。

4374404.review:
Hungarian clone of "Qix", a popular 80's arcade game, with 22 levels with 4 difficulties for just 1 dollar! (the title "Fortix" comes from "Fort + Qix")
Though addition of power-up items and enemy mortality (they can be captured by encircling) makes the game easier than the original, it's still challenging.
It'll take about 10 hours to complete all 4 difficulties. Just play for fun rather than high score (it's highly dependent on luck) or get frustrating.
Crafting a badge is quite easy as a set of only 5 cards are needed.

(Japanese translation below)

==================================================

80年代の人気アーケードゲームQixのハンガリー版クローン、作品名は城塞を意味するFortと原作Qixに由来します。
強化アイテムの導入と敵を囲んで倒せるルールの導入により本家より簡単ですが、それでも歯応えがあり全難易度制覇に約10時間必要です。
運の要素が強いため、スコアは意識しない方がイライラせず楽しめます。
たった1ドルで全22面を4種の難易度で遊べる上に、トレーディングカードが全5種と少なく比較的簡単にバッジを作成できるため、バッジ収集家にも嬉しい作品です。

Fortix is a masterpiece, amazing, sharp graphics and serene music are fused with completely innovative and original gameplay. The story  and lore are beautifully crafted, entwining seamlessly with the fresh, never repititive nature of the gameplay. The controls are also surprisingly responsive, giving players support for both keyboard and mouse which is an achievement in this age of console gaming. 

Fortix far exceeeded my high expectations, it costs as much as a Humble Bundle, but its value reaches far beyond any ordinary game, it is an experience that is both art and entertainment with moral lessons to be learned that would benefit all of humankind. 

This game is not only an example of a game done right, but also an inspiration to other game developers such as myself, for we now have a goal for which we strive towards, a goal of someday, possibly, being able to create as exsquisite a game as this magnificent work of art. 

I award this must-play game: 10/10

Describing a game like Fortix is a difficult task as it does not conform to any familar genre's. At least not any that has had any significant releases in the last ten years. The Fortix type of games are all very similar with very little deviation, you must conquer the land by boxing it in while being attacked by various types of moving and shooting enemies, in this case, Dragons and Towers.

Fortix is a cute little game and it deserves points for not pretending to be anything other than what it is, a cheap little time sink that'll take a couple of hours to complete and a few more to master, It's not normally a type of game I'd recommend to anyone, instead directing them towards the many free flash alternatives however with a measly 1$ price tag, Fortix can hardly be considered a waste of money. Buy it if you're bored and wanna spend a couple of hours "Conquering" the land and "Slaying" dragons.

There's far worse ways you could spend $0.99.

Fortix and its sequel, Fortix 2, are fun little puzzle games in the vein of titles like Lightfish or the classic Qix.

Draw shapes to capture enemies and chunks of the playing field, but don't let them touch the lines you're drawing or you lose a life. A simple concept, but I find it pretty enjoyable.

The sequel has slightly better visuals, and a few new tricks up its sleeve, but you don't have much to lose by giving the original a try, especially for the price.

1888675.review:
This game has a special place in the history of Steam, being the cheapest game available. It has also special place on SteamGifts and in my heart!

The gameplay is simple but surprisingly addictive. You are a knight, tasked to capture enemy forts on a map. You conquer land and anything placed on it simply by drawing a closed line around it, but there be dragons and enemy towers out there to get you. As long as you don't leave the borderline, you're safe though - until time runs out!

You owe it it to yourself to try hard and earn the right to play Fortix!

For what it's worth, it's fun!

Once achievements are at 100% completion however, which isn't extremely hard, you may not feel much incentive to play it further, especially if you own Fortix 2. Unless you are into leaderboard and want to beat me :) Make no mistake, though - it is actually challenging to earn a really high score. Maps have a time limit, so this is not a matter of simple grinding for more score.

3800722.review:
Fortix is heavily inspired by the 1981's arcade game QIX and is a simple, yet addictive medieval-themed puzzle game where you have to capture a castle by fencing it off with lines that you draw on the playfield by moving your character.

The game features 22 levels of increasing difficulty with a handful enemy types such as bats, various dragon types and also cannon towers, which can be destroyed by triggering catapults that are spread across the playfield.

Randomly appearing power ups not only help you to fight the enemies more efficiently, but also help to rack up bigger combos which result in a higher score and a potentially better ranking on the online-leaderboards.

Fortix is a relatively short game and can be beaten in around 1.5-2 hours (maybe even faster if you're not going for a 'Perfect!' on every level), but the 4 difficulty levels add quite a bit to the replayability as they provide an additional challenge.

For only one buck  you certainly can't go wrong on this one! :)

2741220.review:
True to the arcade root of the 1981 Taito game, Qix, Fortix requires players to capture as much land as possible, while evading turrets firing and dragons bashing into your track. For a price-point of $5 on Steam, Fortix definitely offer a nice change of pace to the multi-million budget games, emulating the experience of short Qix gameplay.  

Fortix is far from a good game though. The controls are limited to only keyboard control with the arrows button. The game is short (22 maps at the moment), and could be easily completed within an hour. Music though nice, is limited to only one track. Enemy type are limited to only 4. No tutorial and graphics that are rather backdated (but forgivable, since it was supposed to be released originally for PSP Mini).

While nothing is promised at the moment, Nemesys studio seems keen in community contact, and might expand this game further in the near future. .
